contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox rail | railroad_name = Eastern Counties Railway | logo_filename = | logo_size = | system_map = | map_caption = | map_size = | marks = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | locale = | start_year = 1839 | end_year = 1862 | predecessor_line = | successor_line = [[Great Eastern Railway]] | gauge = {{railgauge|56.5}} (1844-1862) | old_gauge = {{railgauge|60}} (1839-44) | electrification = | length = | hq_city = | website = }} The '''Eastern Counties Railway''' (ECR) was an early [[England|English]] [[railway]] company incorporated in 1836. It was intended to link [[London]] with [[Ipswich]] via [[Colchester]], and then on to [[Norwich]] and [[Great Yarmouth|Yarmouth]]. Construction began in late March 1837 on the first nine miles, at the London end of the line.<ref>{{cite book|author=Gordon, D.PI.|editors=Thomas, David St John and Patmore, J. Allan|title=A Regional History of the Railways of Great Britain — Volume 5: The Eastern Counties|edition=2nd|year=1977|publisher=[[David & Charles]]|location=Newton Abbott}}</ref> Construction was beset by engineering and other problems, leading to severe financial difficulties. As a result the scope of the project was truncated in April 1839 to Colchester. ==Opening== The railway began operating on 20 June 1839 with a train service running from a temporary terminus at {{rws|Devonshire Street}} in [[Mile End]] to [[Romford]], now part of the [[Great Eastern Main Line]]. On 1 July 1840 the line was extended to [[Brentwood, Essex|Brentwood]] and a new London terminus at Shoreditch (renamed [[Bishopsgate railway station|Bishopsgate]] in 1846). The line was subsequently extended, opening on 7 March 1843 to cover the 51 miles between London and [[Colchester]].<ref>{{cite book|author=White, H.P.|editors=Thomas, David St John|title=A Regional History of the Railways of Great Britain — Volume 3: Greater London|edition=3rd|year=1987|publisher=[[David & Charles]]|location=Dawlish}}</ref> ==Track gauge== The ECR tracks were originally set to a [[rail gauge|gauge]] of five feet but between September and October 1844 the gauge was converted to [[standard gauge]] (4′8½″). At the same time the associated [[Northern & Eastern Railway]] was also converted. ==Extensions== ===To Norwich=== ECR trains eventually reached Norwich, but not at first via the Colchester route. Instead it used the route of the originally separate [[Northern & Eastern Railway|Northern & Eastern]] (N&ER) and [[Norwich & Brandon Railway|Norwich & Brandon]] railways, via Stratford, Cambridge, Ely and Brandon. The ECR took the partly completed N&ER on lease on 1 January 1844, the through line to Norwich opening on 30 July 1845. ===To Ipswich=== The Colchester line was extended to [[Ipswich]] in 1846, and to [[Norwich]] in 1849, but via the separate [[Eastern Union Railway]], with which the ECR made an end-on connection. After a period of poor relations, the ECR took over the operation of the EUR on 1 January 1854, a situation formally sanctioned by the Act of 7 August 1854. The merged company in turn, in 1862, amalgamated along with a number of other [[East Anglia]]n railways to form the [[Great Eastern Railway]]. ==Innovations== The ECR is notable as the first company to utilise a two-wheel [[pony truck]] in 1859, using the design of American inventor [[Levi Bissell]]. == References == * ''The Railway Year Book'', 1912 {{Reflist}} [[Category:Railway companies established in 1839]] [[Category:Railway companies disestablished in 1862]] [[Category:Early British railway companies]] [[Category:Pre-grouping British railway companies]] [[Category:History of rail transport in London]]
